author: highlander
title: Smart Contract Library - Phase 1
description: Cardano lacks an open source library of smart contracts that developers can use for rapid prototyping.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposers aims to develop a limited set of smart contract templates for Cardano devs. This projects aligns perfectly with the "Open Source Development Ecosystem" challenge setting, the proposal is therefore regarded impactful from this point of view. The scope is limited into a first phase, which is advantageous since they reduce the risk to over promise and under deliver. The solution will be open source and available to the Cardano development community. There are few valid arguments to not call this proposal impactful and well aligned. As a result, the score in terms of impact will be 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q1: The team behind the proposal are experienced and seems to sit on the right tools to bring their idea to a finished project. Their claims of experience can further be verified and they are deemed credible as a result. The time plan and budget are in line with the expectations given the scope of the project. Given the teams experience and their credibility, there is a high probability that the project will be completed if funded. Score given in terms of feasibility: 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q2: The projects progress will be measured by the number of contracts released and this could be used by the community to audit the progress of the project. It would be advantageous if the proposers set a goal or added some more clearly stated KPI's enabling for an easier auditing. The definition of success is loud and clear and the only thing needed for a 5 star rating in terms of auditability are some clearer goals and relevant KPI's. Score given: 4 stars.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal will be an effective way to help promote building on Cardano. Currently, there are a number of people who are familiar with building on Cardano, However, there are lots of other people that love the idea of it, but don't know how to yet. This program will help allow those people with those desires to educate themselves and become a part of the ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: After looking through the LinkedIn profile of Chris, he seems to understand how to effectively create this "Smart Contract Library". His experience shows that he is familiar with the Cardano languages and is fit to receive funds to create a place where other Cardano users can go to start building themselves.
f6_assessments.q2: The one thing that I would add to this proposal is to find out who the new developer is going to be before this is actually released to the public. Some people may think that some of the other funds are more important than this one, because this fund is essentially paying for someone's job. If we can find out who that person is beforehand, we may have a great proposal here.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposed proposal has a momentum interaction, not too large, focusing mainly on the form of a contract, providing an appropriate solution, assessing the possibility of the solution, stating the risks involved and presenting the solution. solutions by providing documents for users to access and address risks, but more impacts and risks need to be assessed to complete the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: Defining the process, defining a clear time with specific goals in each stage, analyzing in detail the content of the process, a specific budget for each content, each purpose for the contents. spending, but if giving specific salaries to developers will help manage the budget better, the team has come up with a relatively reasonable structure of members.
f6_assessments.q2: Measurements based on contract downloads and project count may not be accurate to reality, the project has not been tested so success is based solely on the proponent's judgment, is project appeared.

f6_assessments.q0: There are a few initiatives and projects which aims to publish Cardano SCs for use cases. However openzipplin project is a huge success in Etherium with more than 8K forks of the code in github. THerefore there is a need to support this project to develop such a repo of Smart Contracts in Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: Purely based on the ownership of the OpenZeppelin repo in GitHub, it can be said that the proposer has enough development capacity to complete the proposal. The GitHub repo of the Etherium projects has about 17K likes and 8 K forks. This is a major success and they are likely to have the potential to replicate it better in Cardano space.
f6_assessments.q2: Ninety per cent of the cost is for hiring a developer 2,080 hours for a year at the rate of 30USD per hour. This is a very reasonable rate for the scope of the work. Availability of preprogrammed smart contracts will substantially flip the outlook towards Cardano.

f6_assessments.q0: A library of smart contract templates would be beneficial for onboarding interested developers. Looking at OpenZeppelin, Decentraland, Gnosis, and a slew other projects have been built thanks to it. If this proposal is successful, it could lead to many new projects to spring up on Cardano. This proposal includes OpenZeppelin's and Cardano's current library; readers can look at both for comparison and judge the thoroughness of the respective websites. What is proposed in this proposal is an introductory series of smart contract templates. This proposal could benefit from including how they wish to scale the library in the future.
f6_assessments.q1: There are clear breakdowns for the timeline and the budget. More information on the team members would be helpful. Only one linkedin page has been shared. As development is involved, github links could also be helpful. NFTS, token issuance and customization, and governance protocols are already being done on Cardano, and some to great success. Has there been any plans to engage with other teams to learn how it has been done so that development time be reduced? How will these smart contract templates differ from other methods? Including some of this technical details could help readers understand more of what the proposal wishes to deliver.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has included links to github and a website in the Impact section where community can track their progress. The proposal states 3 measurements of progress/success: the number of contracts released, number of contract downloads, and number of Cardano projects utilizing the library. The latter two may be out of the team's control but the first one should have a quantifiable number included in the proposal. How many contracts are being delivered by the team by the end of this project?
f6_assessments.reply: The reviewer argues that the proposal should include a specific set of contracts to be developed. The review states, "should have a quantifiable number included in the proposal. How many contracts are being delivered by the team by the end of this project?". However, the proposal mentions three contracts that are to be built during development, "build an introductory series of smart contract templates for token issuance and customization, NFT's, and governance protocols". This review should be removed beacuse if the assesor read the proposal they would have noticied that it included the contracts that are to be developed.

solution: Publish a series of smart contract templates, similar to Ethereum's OpenZeppelin, for Cardano developers.
experience: We are the team behind Highlander, an Ethereum based gaming platform. Chris is our lead developer and has extensive experience developing smart contracts in Solidity and Glow.
